results.title: Gertrud
results.creator_credit: Palladium Films and Carl Theodor Dreyer
results.brief_description: Adapted from a long-forgotten play by Hjalmar Soderberg written during the early years of the 20th century, Dreyer’s controversial last film centres on a proud, stubborn woman who demands total commitment in love and forsakes both her husband and a former lover for a young musician who is relatively indifferent to her. The film moves at a slow, theatrical pace with long takes recorded mainly in direct sound (though shot principally in a studio), and deserves to be ranked along with ‘The Magnificent Ambersons, ‘Lola Montes’, and ‘The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance’ as one of the great haunted-memory films. Its meaning hinges partially on the refusal or inability to compromise and what this implies over the range of an entire life (in this case Dreyer’s as well as his heroine’s). The heroine may be regarded as a monster, a sublime and saintly martyr, or most likely an impossible fusion of the two. Dreyer’s film has a similarly dialectical and contradictory effect—at once narrative and (in the figure of Gertrud herself) nonnarrative, static and flowing, a tribute to free will and a positing of the unconscious as tragic destiny. Reference: Jonathan Rosenbaum. Chicago Online Reader.http://onfilm.chireader.com/MovieCaps/G/GE/03973_GERTRUD.html Cast includes Nina Pens Rode, Bendt Rothe, Ebbe Robe, Baard Owe and Axel Strobye. Note: Adapted from the play by Hjalmar Soderberg. In Danish with English subtitles.

results.title: Gertie the dinosaur
results.brief_description: Gertie the dinosaur the first cartoon of any importance, was produced by Winsor McCay, a cartoonist for the New York American. It features a live-action frame, and approximately ten thousand individual drawings were used for the animation.

results.title: Germination and growth of a plant
results.brief_description:
Use of time-lapse photography showing the growth of a lupin plant. Shows the root growth below the ground, how the flower is pollinated by the bees and the internal germination is carried out - the production of the seed pod and finally the dispersal of the seeds.
Title and credits missing from film.

results.title: Germinal
results.brief_description:
Etienne is a young man who seeks work in the coal mines of the North of France. After experiencing the harsh working conditions of the mine, he becomes a labor activist and tries to organize a strike to improve wages and conditions. Etienne is also tormented by the mine owner, whose promiscuous wife steps out on him at will. Etienne falls in love with the daughter of a fellow miner. Her loyalty to her father and the fear he might lose his job makes her initially unresponsive to Etienne’s romantic advances.

Credits: Producer, Eugene Tuchere ; director, Yves Allegret ; writer, Charles Spaak ; photography, Jean Bourgoin ; music, Michel Magne ; art direction, Lucien Aguettand.
Cast: Jean Sorel, Berthe Grandval, Lea Padovani, Claude Brasseur, Bernard Blier.

results.title: Germany: People of the industrial West
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and John T. Bobbitt
results.brief_description: Describes the life of people on Western Germany depicting them in a variety of occupations form the southern uplands to the Western plains in the country, village and city. Tells something of the history and cultural past of the Germans and gives an idea of life today in the major regions of Germany - the Rhineland, and uplands of the south, and the northern plains. Emphasizes the reconstruction of prosperity in spite of Germany’s war devastation and partition.

results.title: Germany: Key to Europe
results.brief_description: A report on the German problem, showing how events since World War II have made this divided nation an area of conflict between two ideologies. The film brings into focus the march of events that followed the country’s collapse and its military occupations. The political manoeuvres of the Social bloc to build a satellite state, in opposition to the wish of the Western powers for a unified, democratic Germany, are seen as major factors in the struggle.

results.title: Germany: Feudal states to unification
results.brief_description: Traces Prussia’s growth in strength in the nineteenth century. Shows how other German states were brought under its control and how the wars with Denmark, Austria and France were fought.

results.title: Germany: A regional geography
results.creator_credit: Greenpark Productions, G. Buckland-Smith and Clive Rees
results.brief_description: Regional differentiation within Western Germany reflects the varied physical geography. Contrasts the Black Forest with the more active Rhinelands whose economic importance is accentuated by the proximity of the Ruhr coalfields. The historic south is in direct contrast with the recently reclaimed North Coast. The final sequence shows Berlin epitomising the East-West political division and the rapid post war economic recovery.

results.title: Germany through the eyes of its youth
results.brief_description: German children express their feelings about the division of Germany in various art forms, painting, drawing, and modelling. Students selected from 80,000 entrants give impressions of ‘indivisible Germany’. These dramatic visualisations range from conventional pencil drawing and painting, to collages, bas-reliefs, and sculpture, all conveying the intensity of feeling Germany’s youth has toward reunifying their country. ‘All Germany at one table’ is an often heard slogan in the west.

results.title: Germany of today
results.creator_credit: Greenpark Productions, G. Buckland-Smith and Clive Rees
results.brief_description: Traces the evolution of Germany from Charlemagne ti the present day. Stresses early disunity and rivalries of Emperor, Princes and Church. Unification in the 19th century; destruction in the Second World War followed by a rapid economic recovery, epitomised in the changing face of Bonn the new Federal Capital. Early history is portrayed in architecture, sculpture and art.
